commit_list.message:
Update bundler version

Changes since last version used (1.14.6):

== 1.15.1 (2017-06-02)

Bugfixes:

  - `bundle lock --update GEM` will fail gracefully when the gem is not in the lockfile (bundler/bundler#5693, @segiddins)
  - `bundle init --gemspec` will fail gracefully when the gemspec is invalid (@colby-swandale)
  - `bundle install --force` works when the gemfile contains git gems (bundler/bundler#5678, @segiddins)
  - `bundle env` will print well-formed markdown when there are no settings (bundler/bundler#5677, @segiddins)

== 1.15.0 (2017-05-19)

This space intentionally left blank.

== 1.15.0.pre.4 (2017-05-10)

Bugfixes:

  - avoid conflicts when `Gem.finish_resolve` is called after the bundle has been set up (@segiddins)
  - ensure that `Gem::Specification.find_by_name` always returns an object that can have `#to_spec` called on it (bundler/bundler#5592, @jules2689)

== 1.15.0.pre.3 (2017-04-30)

Bugfixes:

  - avoid redundant blank lines in the readme generated by `bundle gem` (@koic)
  - ensure that `open-uri` is not loaded after `bundle exec` (@segiddins)
  - print a helpful error message when an activated default gem conflicts with
    a gem in the gemfile (@segiddins)
  - only shorten `ref` option for git gems when it is a SHA (bundler/bundler#5620, @segiddins)

== 1.15.0.pre.2 (2017-04-23)

Bugfixes:

  - ensure pre-existing fit caches are updated from remote sources (bundler/bundler#5423, @alextaylor000)
  - avoid duplicating specs in the lockfile after updating with the gem uninstalled (bundler/bundler#5599, @segiddins)
  - ensure git gems have their extensions available at runtime (bundler/bundler#5594, @jules2689, @segiddins)

== 1.15.0.pre.1 (2017-04-16)

Features:

  - print a notification when a newer version of bundler is available (bundler/bundler#4683, @segiddins)
  - add man pages for all bundler commands (bundler/bundler#4988, @feministy)
  - add the `bundle info` command (@fredrb, @colby-swandale)
  - all files created with `bundle gem` comply with the bundler style guide (@zachahn)
  - if installing a gem fails, print out the reason the gem needed to be installed (bundler/bundler#5078, @segiddins)
  - allow setting `gem.push_key` to set the key used when running `rake release` (@DTrierweiler)
  - print gem versions that are regressing during `bundle update` in yellow (bundler/bundler#5506, @brchristian)
  - avoid printing extraneous dependencies when the resolver encounters a conflict (@segiddins)
  - add the `bundle issue` command that prints instructions for reporting issues (bundler/bundler#4871, @jonathanpike)
  - add `--source` and `--group` options to the `bundle inject` command (bundler/bundler#5452, @Shekharrajak)
  - add the `bundle add` command to add a gem to the gemfile (@denniss)
  - add the `bundle pristine` command to re-install gems from cached `.gem` files (bundler/bundler#4509, @denniss)
  - add a `--parseable` option for `bundle config` (@JuanitoFatas, @colby-swandale)

Performance:

  - speed up gemfile initialization by storing locked dependencies as a hash (@jules2689)
  - speed up gemfile initialization by making locked dependency comparison lazy, avoiding object allocation (@jules2689)
  - only validate git gems when they are downloaded, instead of every time `Bundler.setup` is run (@segiddins)
  - avoid regenerating the lockfile when nothing has changed (@segiddins)
  - avoid diffing large arrays when no sources in the gemfile have changed (@segiddins)
  - avoid evaluating full gemspecs when running with RubyGems 2.5+ (@segiddins)

Bugfixes:

  - fix cases where `bundle update` would print a resolver conflict instead of updating the selected gems (bundler/bundler#5031, bundler/bundler#5095, @segiddins)
  - print out a stack trace after an interrupt when running in debug mode (@segiddins)
  - print out when bundler starts fetching a gem from a remote server (@segiddins)
  - fix `bundle gem` failing when `git` is unavailable (bundler/bundler#5458, @Shekharrajak, @colby-swandale)
  - suggest the appropriate command to unfreeze a bundle (bundler/bundler#5009, @denniss)
  - ensure nested calls to `bundle exec` resolve default gems correctly (bundler/bundler#5500, @segiddins)
  - ensure that a plugin failing to install doesn't uninstall other plugins (@kerrizor, @roseaboveit)
  - ensure `socket` is required before being referenced (bundler/bundler#5533, @rafaelfranca)
  - allow running `bundle outdated` when gems aren't installed locally (bundler/bundler#5553, @segiddins)
  - print a helpful error when `bundle exec`ing to a gem that isn't included in the bundle (bundler/bundler#5487, @segiddins)
  - print an error message when a non-git gem is given a `branch` option (bundler/bundler#5530, @colby-swandale)
  - allow interrupts to exit the process after gems have been installed (@segiddins)
  - print the underlying error when downloading gem metadata fails (bundler/bundler#5579, @segiddins)
  - avoid deadlocking when installing with a lockfile that is missing dependencies (bundler/bundler#5378, bundler/bundler#5480, bundler/bundler#5519, bundler/bundler#5526, bundler/bundler#5529, bundler/bundler#5549, bundler/bundler#5572, @segiddins)

Update RC2 bundler version

Keeping up-to-date with production.

Update RC2 bundler version

Keeping up-to-date with production.

Update postgres

The version currently used in RC2 production is 9.6.6.

Validating API url and key

Stop assigning input values on submit

commit_list.repo_description: Web app that consumes the Fyber Offer API and renders its responses.

commit_list.message:
HTTP with Curb

Changed the default client to Curb and abstracted its interface with an adapter class.

This class is a simple object that will be instantiated and then called on get with the url to make the request.

With Curb there's the benefit of keep-alive connections without being constrained by a block.

commit_list.message:
Adding a requester! To make requests!

Now, finally, requests can be made in a more sane way.

The Requester class will take care of all the HTTP nastiness.
It's job is to only make the request, parse the JSON body and pass it
along.

Also added a VCR to record all this interactions.

commit_list.message:
Making a better client

Now it's time to make a client that will request those offers for the
web thing.

It will receive all the necessary parameters to make a successful
request, add that special hashkey and done.

The client class responsibility will be to deal with the params and
delegate the rest, mainly coordinating stuff. The others are
self-explanatory, I think...

commit_list.message:
Wrapping the HTTP response in an object

API::Requester now wraps the HTTP response in an instance of the class
API::Response.

The response object is responsible for parsing the JSON and validating
the Fyber code. If its an error or unknown code it will raise an error.

commit_list.message:
Add vim plugin lifepillar/pgsql.vim

Replace the old exu/pgsql.vim because this one is more up to date and
has better support for some Postgres extensions.

Delete ctrlp config from vimrc

The vim plugin CtrlP was removed.

Add vim plugin ivalkeen/vim-simpledb

The simplest and best plugin to run SQL DB queries.
Change vim plugin neomake repo

Add vim plugin kassio/neoterm

Better way to deal with Neovim terminals. It keeps the same instance
open so the history is not lost.

It will also be used by vim-test.

Set vim config updatetime

Decrease default time of 4 seconds to 250 miliseconds so gitgutter can
refresh faster.

Change vim clipboard setting

Following Neovim recomendation to use the clipboard for all operations.

Don't show vim mode below the statusline

The statusline, with the help of vim-airline, will show the current vim
mode.

Replace vim plugin scrooloose/syntastic for benekastah/neomake

Neomake uses asychronous job processing, the linting commands are fired
off in the background, resulting in the elimination of those annoying
wait-times in between saves you will experience with Syntastic in
traditional vim.

Currently, Neomake will run asynchronously only with Neovim. On Vim it
will run synchronously.

Set vim configs conditionally

Neovim set a lot of great configs by default.
Settings needed only by vim are not set when using neovim.

Add vim plugin reedes/vim-pencil

Better support for writing prose-oriented files, such as markdown.
Use neovim as git editor

Ignore files used by foreman/forego in development

This files must always be ignored.

Only an example should be commited in the repos.

Change pg_restore alias pgr

The `clean` parameter was raising errors when trying to drop some
tables.

Now the database must be cleaned before hand.
Fix install script typo

Fix tmux mouse support

After tmux 2.1 the mouse support changed and the old configurations
stopped working.

Now it works with the plugin nhdaly/tmux-scroll-copy-mode plus the
option `set-option -g mouse on`.

Change TPM script to install plugins

The script used to install TPM plugins chaged its path.

Check for Darwin on OSX specifics

The command `brew` is expected only on OSX, so it will only be used
there.

Change install script

The -h argument only works on OSX and its not that much of a
requirement.
It just says to not follow symbolic links. Which we'll really try not to
do.

Change install script

Neovim uses the XDG config now.
It will not use .nvimrc anymore.

Add plugin tmux-yank

So I can use the same command on Mac and Linux.

Using neovim strategy in vim-test

Now, vim-test uses this same custom function for neovim.

Remove nvimrc

Neovim must use the regular vimrc :)

Change install script

- Using Plug instead of Vundle to handle vim plugins
- Neovim configs will be symlinked to the regular vim ones
- If git isn't found than shows a message asking to install

Add vim plugin tpope/vim-bundler

From the doc:
This lightweight companion to rails.vim and rake.vim provides support for
Bundler.  In addition to the bundle commands, it also syntax highlights
Gemfile and Gemfile.lock, and alters 'path' and 'tags' to include bundled
gems.

Add vim plugin tpope/vim-rake

From the docs:
This plugin is designed to let you use your favorite rails.vim commands in a
plain old Ruby project.

Projects are detected by searching for a Rakefile up the directory hierarchy.
Projects without a Rakefile will also be detected if they sit inside the gem
path, making this plugin ideal for "gem open" or "bundle open".

Reorganize Vims plugin list

Organizing to better deal with the plugins.

Add plugin airblade/vim-gitgutter

A Vim plugin which shows a git diff in the 'gutter' (sign column). It
shows whether each line has been added, modified, and where lines have
been removed. You can also stage and revert individual hunks.

Add plugin tpope/vim-vinegar

Enhance vims default project browser (netrw).

Add this functionality (from README):

  * Press - in any buffer to hop up to the directory listing and seek to
    the file you just came from. Keep bouncing to go up, up, up. Having
    rapid directory access available changes everything.
  * All that annoying crap at the top is turned off, leaving you with
    nothing but a list of files. This is surprisingly disorienting, but
    ultimately very liberating. Press I to toggle until you adapt.
  * The oddly C-biased default sort order and file hiding is replaced with a
    sensible application of 'suffixes' and 'wildignore'.
  * Press . on a file to pre-populate it at the end of a : command line.
    This is great, for example, to quickly initiate a :grep of the file
    or directory under the cursor. There's also !, which starts the line
    off with a bang. Type !chmod +x and get :!chmod +x path/to/file.
  * Press cg or cl to :cd or :lcd to the currently edited directory.
  * Press ~ to go home.

Add plugin tpope/vim-projectionist

This plugin provides the same navigational functionality of rails.vim
for non rails projects (of any kind and of any language/framework)

For example, with rails.vim you can do that in a rails project:

:Emodel user       # opens in the current buffer the file for the model user
:Tcontroller users # opens in a new tab the file for the users controller
:Slib utils        # opens in a split the file utils.rb in lib
:A  # when in some ruby file tries to open the alternate file (eg: test)
:R  # when in some ruby file tries to open the related file (eg: migration)
:AV # opens the alternate file in a vertical split

That same functionality can be achieved with projectionist for any
project, after some initial configuration.

Remove color plugin vim-hemisu

Not really using it.
Solarized and Seoul256 is enough for me.

Change test mappings for vim-test

The plan is to go back to only one vim configuration.
In that case, Neovim configs will be symlinked to Vims (vimrc and .vim).

It levarages Neovim embedded terminal to run the tests.

Using diff-so-fancy for better git diffs

diff-so-fancy builds on the good-lookin' output of git contrib's
diff-highlight to upgrade your diffs' appearances.

- Output will not be in standard patch format, but will be readable.
- No pesky + or - at line-start, making for easier copy-paste.

Repo: https://github.com/so-fancy/diff-so-fancy

Update `bin/replace` script for better portability

The existing implementation of the `replace` script does not work on
GNU/Linux due to differences in the implementation of `sed`. This change
reworks the process of the replacement to create temporary files,
apply the changes to the files, and then move them into place. It will
improve the script's portability for more OSes.

--
Overwrite internal field separator when replacing.
Problem:
Currently the `for` in bash will break up lists by whitespace, so if a
filename has a space in it the `for` will break it up incorrectly.

AG will separate the files with a newline character, so this temporarily
overwrites the `IFS` to be used correctly for this use case.

[Docs](https://bash.cyberciti.biz/guide/$IFS)

Replace vim languages plugins for vim-polyglot

Instead of searching and adding a plugin for each language it's better
not to think about this.

== vim-polyglot (https://github.com/sheerun/vim-polyglot)

A collection of language packs for Vim.

- It won't affect your startup time, as scripts are loaded only on demand*.
- It installs and updates 100+ times faster* than 100+ packages it consist of.
- Solid syntax and indentation support. Only the best language packs.
- All unnecessary files are ignored (like enormous documentation from php support).
- No support for esoteric languages, only most popular ones (modern too, like `slim`).
- Each build is tested by automated vimrunner script on CI. See `spec` directory.

* To be completely honest, concatenated `ftdetect` script takes around `3ms` to load.

https://github.com/tmux/tmux/commit/76d6d3641f271be1756e41494960d96714e7ee58

Besides updating the syntax, adds more bindings.

Python and pip and company need this path.

Add vim plugin tmux-plugins/vim-tmux-focus-events

`FocusGained` and `FocusLost` autocommand events are not working in
terminal vim. This plugin restores them when using vim inside Tmux.

Here's where that matters:

- tpope/vim-fugitive plugin uses `FocusGained` for refreshing git branch
  in status line
- airblade/vim-gitgutter uses `FocusGained` for refreshing the git gutter

Also, `vim-tmux-focus-events` makes the `autoread` option work properly
for terminal vim. So far, this was only working in a GUI version.

The `autoread` feature comes handy when files are changed outside vim, for
example when resolving merge conflicts. When you come back to vim and try saving
a changed file you'll likely be interrupted with E813*.

Improved `autoread` prevents this by automatically reading a file from disk
if it was changed. Works only if `autoread` option is set (enable it with
`set autoread` in `.vimrc`).

* http://vimdoc.sourceforge.net/htmldoc/editing.html#E813

Restore tmux prefix config

The plugin tmux-sensible doesn't set this prefix. To use a more sane one
this needs to be set manually.
